awd_abstract_narration:
This award is made as part of the FY 2022 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist.

The title of the project for this fellowship to Ray Li is "Coding Theory: Deletions, List decoding, and Beyond." The host institution for the fellowship is the University of California Berkeley, and the sponsoring scientist is Venkatesan Guruswami.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project funded the postdoctoral studies of Ray Li at UC Berkeley. This proejct studied error-correcting codes, combinatorial objects that protect data from noise in various contexts. Error-correcting codes find a variety of applications in areas such as communication, storage, algorithms, computational complexity, and cryptography. The goal of this project was to study error-correcting codes in two contexts, deletion errors and list-decoding, and explore the connections of these ideas to other areas of mathematics and computer science. 

This project produced five papers

  • The first paper (He, Li, 2023) discovers a novel connection between deletions codes and the algorithmic question of approximating Longest Common Subsequence, resolving a fundamental open question for one of the most classic algorithmic problems. This work was published in STOC 2023.
  • The second paper (Alrabiah, Guruswami, Li) shows that Reed-Solomon codes are list-decodable to capacity with best possible linear alphabet size, and that random-linear codes are list-decodable to capacity with near-optimal alphabet size and optimal list-size. Both results concern long-standing and well-studied questions in list-decoding. This paper is in submission.
  • The third paper (Alrabiah, Guruswami, Li) gives novel lower bounds for list-decodable codes and shows a surprising dichotomy between list-decoding and unique-decoding. This paper has been accepted to SODA 2024.
  • The fourth paper (Baspin, Krishna, Guruswami, Li) studies quantum error-correcting codes. It proves new results about how limited connectivity --- a requirement for physically realizable quantum codes --- constrains the quality of quantum codes. This paper was presented as a poster at QEC 2023, and is in submission.
  • The fifth paper (Abboud, Dalirrooyfard, Li, Vassilevska-Williams) is unrelated to coding theory. It studies graph diameter, a fundamental measure of the connectedness of a graph that is of theoretical and practical importance. This paper finds faster algorithms for and proved new algorithmic barriers for various notions of diameter in directed graphs. This work was published in ESA 2023.

This project provided a valuable educational opportunity, allowing the PI to branch out into a new area, quantum error-correcting codes. While funded by this project, the PI also contributed problems to high school competitions in the United States, including for the National Science Bowl and team selection tests for the International Math Olympiad (IMO) and the European Girls Math Olympiad (EGMO).
